subject: Re: [junit] Re: Expected exception pitfall and pattern
msgSnippet: ... Not quite, because 10 FAILURES might mean that there are really ten broken tests, or that there is one broken and nine that failed because that first one
messageBody:
On 11/29/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
>
> On 30/11/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > Why work on it if the testing framework can do it for you?
> >
> > Without dependent methods: "10 FAILURES".
> >
> > With dependent methods: "1 FAILURE, 9 SKIPS".
> >
> > I know which result I prefer :-)
>
> They both say the same thing to me: I've got something that, if it is
> broken, affects lots of tests.


Not quite, because "10 FAILURES" might mean that there are really ten broken
tests, or that there is one broken and nine that failed because that first
one failed. Or the break down could be 2/8. Or 3/7. Or... you get the
idea.

Over the years, I have learned to mistrust the results that JUnit gives me
for that reaon. I read "10 FAILURES" and deep inside, I know that "nah,
it's not really ten failures".

And it's so easy for the testing framework to provide accurate reports if it
gets a little help from the developer...

--
Cédric


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
